s1: Cyber Security Foundations introduces all essential cyber security principles.
s2: The course also aims to give an overview of the historical, philosophical, and logical foundations of AI.

s1: This includes principles of secure design, secrets minimization, least privilege, isolation, separation and encapsulation.
s2: The focus of this course is on core AI techniques for search, knowledge representation and reasoning, planning, and designing intelligent agents.

s1: The interplay between failed security principles and vulnerabilities is investigated in detail.
s2: The course also aims to give an overview of the historical, philosophical, and logical foundations of AI.

s1: The course provides the essential foundations which allow students to continue in a more in-depth cyber security career, yet can also be used a standalone unit to provide a self-contained set of knowledge.
s2: The focus of this course is on core AI techniques for search, knowledge representation and reasoning, planning, and designing intelligent agents.

s1: Demonstrate a thorough understanding of the fundamental principles underlying Cyber Security.
s2: The course also aims to give an overview of the historical, philosophical, and logical foundations of AI.

s1: Define and identify cyber security principles and their violation.
s2: Design and perform an empirical evaluation of different algorithms on a problem formalisation, and state the conclusions that the evaluation supports.

s1: Apply cyber security principles in a practical context.
s2: The focus of this course is on core AI techniques for search, knowledge representation and reasoning, planning, and designing intelligent agents.

s1: Migrate insights from cyber security analysis into new designs.
s2: Design and perform an empirical evaluation of different algorithms on a problem formalisation, and state the conclusions that the evaluation supports.

s1: Communicate a cyber security thread to a heterogenous team of professionals.
s2: Design and perform an empirical evaluation of different algorithms on a problem formalisation, and state the conclusions that the evaluation supports.
